title-group.article-title: An exhaust gas recirculation control strategy for passenger car diesel engines using an inverse valve model

abstract.p: In diesel engines, accurate control of the exhaust gas recirculation (EGR) is important because of its effects on the nitrogen oxide and particulate matter emissions. The conventional EGR control system adopts a simple proportional–integral (PI) control algorithm with a lookup-table-based feedforward control and gain scheduling. However, this lookup-table-based control system has limited control performance in transient operations because the lookup tables are obtained from static engine data.

The objective of this paper is to improve the control performance of the diesel engine EGR system by using a mathematical model of the EGR path. The proposed EGR control system is composed of PI controller gain scheduling and a feedforward control algorithm based on the mathematical model. The gain-scheduling algorithm provides a PI controller gain based on a sensitivity function that elucidates the relationship between the effective flow area of the EGR valve and the EGR mass flowrate. The feedforward algorithm calculates the EGR valve position based on the inverse model of the EGR valve.

The driving cycle test result showed that, compared with the conventional EGR control system, the r.m.s. and maximum values of the target tracking error were reduced by 2.5 per cent and 8.0 per cent respectively.

sec.title: 1 Introduction
sec.p: Diesel engines are frequently used in vehicle powertrains because of their high fuel efficiency. However, because of their lean combustion characteristics, diesel engines suffer from nitrogen oxide (NOx) emissions problems. Research on exhaust gas recirculation (EGR), homogeneous charge compression ignition, lean NOx traps (LNTs), and selective catalytic reduction (SCR) have been carried out with the goal of reducing NOx emissions [1, 2]. Among these methods, the EGR approach is the most promising for reducing in-cylinder NOx formation [3–9]. An adequate exhaust gas density in the cylinder charge effectively reduces NOx emissions, but an excessively large EGR rate results in particulate matter emissions [10, 11]. Therefore, accurate control of the EGR is required to reduce harmful emissions.

The purpose of EGR control is the regulation of the EGR mass flowrate. However, in internal combustion engines, the EGR mass flow cannot be measured directly using sensors. For this reason, in the early phase, an open-loop EGR control strategy based on a lookup table is widely used. In order to improve the EGR control performance, closed-loop EGR control strategies based on an exhaust gas oxygen (EGO) sensor were proposed. The proposed control system uses a linear air system model and a linear quadratic Gaussian–loop transfer recovery control algorithm [12]. However, the EGO-sensor-based control system has a high system time constant because of the slow dynamics of the EGO sensor [3].

A simplified three-state model of the diesel engine air system was proposed and widely applied to the model-based air charge control algorithm [13]. The three-state model adopts the intake manifold pressure, the exhaust manifold pressure, and the compressor power as the state variables. The model also adopts the EGR mass flowrate and the turbine mass flowrate as the system inputs. The proposed three-state model is not practical, since the system inputs cannot be measured and cannot be freely manipulable.

The conventional EGR control system uses a mass airflow (MAF) sensor to infer the EGR mass flowrate [14, 15]. For this reason, the EGR mass flowrate is controlled by adjusting the EGR valve position based on measurements from the MAF sensor, which is located upstream of the compressor.

The conventional EGR control algorithm is composed of a proportional–integral (PI) feedback controller and a feedforward controller based on lookup tables [15–17]. The feedback controller calculates the control signal based on the deviation between the target MAF and the measured MAF. The PI controller gains are read from lookup tables which utilize the engine-operating conditions as the input variables. In the same way, the feedforward control output is read from a lookup table. However, these lookup tables are derived from static engine data and require the compilation of data from many experiments, incurring significant development cost and time. In addition, the lookup tables use the engine rotational speed and the fuelling rate as input variables, neither of which has a direct relationship to the EGR mass flowrate. The EGR mass flowrate is affected by the EGR valve lift and the thermodynamic properties of the EGR path such as the pressure and the temperature. For this reason, to achieve fast and accurate EGR control performance, the physical behaviour of the target system must be considered in the control algorithm.

In this paper, an EGR control scheme based on the physical model of the EGR path is presented. The proposed approach used a gain-scheduling method based on the input–output sensitivity of the EGR system, defined as the ratio of the EGR mass flowrate to the effective flow area (EFA) of the EGR valve. In addition, feedforward EGR control using an inverse valve model was implemented. As a result, the control performance was improved, and time-consuming engine calibration work was reduced by replacing the lookup tables in the conventional control algorithm with the mathematical model of the EGR flow.

sec.title: 2 Description of the Diesel Engine Air System
sec.p: Numerous engine models based on mathematical and physical behaviour have been developed and are generally used for control design, optimization, and system analysis [18–20]. To enhance the control performance, the EGR mass flow model was derived and then the linear controller gains and the feedforward control output were obtained using the EGR mass flow model.

In this study, a 3.0 l common-rail direct-injection diesel engine was used for the modelling, analysis, and validation of the EGR control system. The target engine air system was composed of the four subsystems shown in Fig. 1: a variable-geometry turbocharger (VGT), a d.c.-motor-type EGR valve, an intercooler, and an EGR cooler.

sec.title: 2.1 EGR mass flow model
sec.p: The EGR valve is located between the exhaust manifold and the EGR cooler. In this study, the orifice equation was used to derive the mass flowrate through the EGR valve [7]. The EFA of the EGR valve is affected by several factors, such as the EGR valve position, the valve-filling dynamics, the pressure loss, the EGR flowrate, and the EGR cooling efficiency. Among these factors, the EGR valve position has the dominant effect on the EFA, as shown in Fig. 2. For this reason, many EGR control algorithms use a simplified EFA model, which is a function of the EGR valve lift.

sec.title: 2.2 Cylinder charge model
sec.p: The total mass flowrate into the cylinder was derived from the speed–density method based on the volumetric efficiency during steady state operation [7]. The volumetric efficiency is a parameter used to measure the effectiveness of an engine’s induction process. The EGR and cylinder mass flow models were validated through engine experiments. Since the EGR mass flowrate cannot be measured using a sensor, MAF information was used to validate the EGR mass flow model. The MAF was calculated using the mass conservation law in the intake manifold. Figure 3 compares the measured MAF data and the MAF results from the air path model. The measured MAF and calculated MAF values showed similar behaviours, and the intake manifold model provided faster MAF information than did the measured MAF.

sec.title: 3 EGR Control Strategy
sec.p: In diesel engines, the EGR valve is controlled to reduce the deviation between the target MAF and the measured MAF. The target MAF tracking performance is important owing to its effect on harmful emissions. This section introduces a modified EGR control algorithm which improves the MAF control performance relative to that of the conventional control system.

sec.title: 3.1 Disadvantages of the conventional EGR control algorithm
sec.p: The conventional EGR control algorithm is composed of a PI feedback control and a feedforward control as shown in Fig. 4 [15–17]. The feedforward controller is employed to enhance the transient control performance because the feedforward output is immediately calculated on the basis of the engine operating conditions such as the engine speed and the fuelling rate. However, these operating conditions have no direct connection to the EGR mass flowrate. Moreover, the lookup table requires numerous engine experiments to derive optimized data. To improve the control performance and to reduce the number of experiments required to derive the optimized lookup tables, it is necessary to consider the physical characteristics of the EGR system in the control algorithm.

sec.title: 3.2 Feedforward control based on the inverse valve model
sec.p: Feedforward control is frequently used in control system design applications in which the process or controlled variable behaviour is well understood. Combined feedforward and feedback controls can improve the control performance more than simple feedback control can, whenever there is a measurable disturbance [21].

In EGR valve control, the intake and exhaust manifold pressures are the measurable disturbances. In this study, a feedforward EGR control algorithm based on the EGR valve model was applied [22, 23]. The key ingredients of the feedforward control are the intake manifold model, the inverse valve flow model, and the inverse poppet valve model. The feedforward algorithm is described in Fig. 5.

sec.title: 3.2.4 Validation of the feedforward control output
sec.p: An engine experiment was performed to assess the validity of the feedforward control output. Figure 6 compares the feedforward EGR valve lift and the measured EGR valve lift during a New European Driving Cycle (NEDC) test. The difference between the feedforward output and the measured output signifies the error in the feedforward control algorithm. As shown in Fig. 6, the error between the feedforward and the measured EGR valve positions was relatively large at low loads and engine speeds, e.g. 1300 r/min and 50 N m for 900–960 s. This error arises because the EGR valve flow is close to a singular point at low loads and engine speeds, where the pressure ratio across the EGR valve is close to one.

sec.title: 3.3 Gain-scheduling algorithm
sec.p: The air path in a diesel engine is a highly non-linear system. Hence, the target value tracking performance differs with the engine operating point when using a linear controller. To address this problem, a linear controller operating according to a gain-scheduling method is frequently used in various control applications.

Gain scheduling is a useful technique for reducing the effects of the variations in the parameters in a control system. This method involves a special type of non-linear feedback with linear controller parameters that change in a programmed manner as a function of the operating conditions [21]. The conventional EGR control system adopts a lookup-table-based gain-scheduled linear controller that requires a large number of engine experiments for optimization. In order to reduce the number of time-consuming experiments, in this study, a gain-scheduling method is proposed for the EGR control system based on the measurement of thermodynamic properties of the air system such as the pressure and the temperature.

sec.title: 3.3.1 Input–output sensitivity analysis
sec.p: In non-linear or parameter-varying systems, the input–output sensitivity can vary with the operating point, making it necessary to adjust the linear controller gain based on the system sensitivity. In this study, the sensitivity of the system was defined as the ratio of the output to the input of the EGR mass flow model, where the output was the EGR mass flowrate, and the input was the EFA. the sensitivity is a function of parameters such as the inlet and outlet pressures and the inlet temperature of the EGR valve. Figure 7 shows the effects of the pressure and the temperature on the input–output sensitivity. As the simulation results show, the sensitivity increased when the pressure ratio decreased or when the exhaust gas temperature increased. The level of sensitivity signified the rate of change in the EGR mass flowrate at the corresponding EFA. In other words, at a high sensitivity value, the variation in the EGR mass flowrate was higher than that at a lower sensitivity value.

sec.title: 3.3.2 Gain-scheduling algorithm
sec.p: In a non-linear system, the controller gain must change according to the operating point. For instance, the linear controller gain must be increased to reduce the response time at an operating point with low sensitivity. In contrast, the linear controller gain must be decreased to prevent unstable operation at an operating point with high sensitivity.

The input–output sensitivity, obtained using equation (7), was used to calculate the linear controller gains. In this study, the PI controller gains were multiplied by the reciprocal of the input–output sensitivity. The overall controller gains increased when the input–output sensitivity decreased, indicating that more control effort was applied to the target plant when the system sensitivity was low. As a result, the target value tracking performance was improved compared with that of the fixed-gain controller under all operating conditions. Figure 8 depicts the block diagram of the proposed EGR control algorithm composed of the PI feedback control, the feedforward control, and the gain-scheduling algorithm based on the EGR valve model.

sec.title: 4 Experimental Apparatus
sec.p: To analyse and validate the proposed EGR control algorithm, an engine experimental apparatus was set up on an engine dynamometer. This study used a 3.0 l six-cylinder common-rail direct-injection diesel engine equipped with a VGT and a cooled EGR. The specifications of the engine are detailed in Table 1.

Figure 9 shows the configuration of the experimental apparatus including the engine, dynamometer, controllers, and connections. The proposed EGR control algorithm was implemented on a commercial rapid control prototyping tool, dSPACE MicroAutoBox. The EGR control algorithm calculated the valve position, and a separate motor driver operated the d.c.-motor-type EGR valve to set the valve position.

caption.p: Schematic diagram of the experimental apparatus (RPM, engine speed (r/min))

sec.p: In the experiment, the engine operating conditions that were used in the control algorithm, such as the engine rotational speed, the fuelling rate, and the intake manifold pressure, were measured using standard automotive sensors. Two sensors, namely the exhaust manifold pressure sensor and the intake manifold temperature sensor, were supplementally installed in the engine to calculate the EGR mass flowrate.

sec.title: 5 Simulation and Experimental Results
sec.p: To examine the feasibility and to validate the developed control algorithm, engine simulations were carried out using the commercial engine model TESIS enDYNA, a mean-value model based on physical equations. After that, the developed control algorithm was validated through a driving cycle test using an engine dynamometer.

sec.title: 5.1 Closed-loop frequency response analysis (simulation)
sec.p: In this study, a closed-loop frequency response simulation was carried out to examine the feasibility and performance of the proposed EGR control algorithm. The closed-loop frequency response signifies the steady state response of a system to sinusoidal inputs at various frequencies [24]. This is a useful method for measuring the maximum reference input frequency traceable by the control system. In the frequency response, the bandwidth is defined as the frequency at which the closed-loop magnitude, the ratio of the input to the measured output, is equal to −3 dB. The bandwidth indicates how well the closed-loop control system will track the reference input signal. In this simulation, the input and output of the closed-loop frequency response were the target MAF and the measured MAF, as shown in Fig. 10. To investigate the effects of the feedforward control and gain scheduling, the following five sets of closed-loop controllers were compared:

sec.p: In contrast, controllers (a) and (b), composed of the PI controller and a lookup table-based feedforward controller, showed the smallest bandwidths. These results indicate that the model-based feedforward control and gain scheduling improved the response of the closed-loop control system.

Feedforward control had a greater effect on the bandwidth of the closed-loop control system than did the gain scheduling, as shown in Figs 11(1) to Figs 11(4). This phenomenon was particularly significant at low engine speeds as the EGR system had a low sensitivity under those conditions. For this reason, the feedforward control had a significant effect on the bandwidth at low speeds compared with the effect of the feedback control.

The closed-loop frequency response simulation demonstrated the feasibility of the model-based EGR control. As the simulation result showed, the target value tracking performance was improved by applying the EGR valve model to the control algorithm. However, compared with the conventional EGR control algorithm, the proposed EGR control strategy requires additional unmeasured information such as the exhaust manifold pressure and the intake manifold temperature.

Although a model-based approach can exhibit an improved control performance, any increased cost using additional sensors restricts the implementation of the proposed EGR control algorithm into the production engine management system. This problem regarding the cost can be solved by sensor technology or engine modelling and estimation technology.

sec.p: To validate the performance of the proposed EGR control algorithm, driving cycle tests were performed using an engine dynamometer. In this study, the NEDC, which is composed of four ECE-15 driving cycles and an Extra-Urban Driving Cycle, was used. sec.p: As seen in Figs 12 to 14, the PI controller had a limited control performance since it calculated the control output using measurement feedback. In comparison, the EGR control based on the physical model showed a relatively fast tracking performance. Because the feedforward EGR valve position was immediately calculated from the target MAF and EGR, the valve model and feedforward output instantly affected the system output. For this reason, the feedforward control enhanced the transient control performance.

The maximum error, the standard deviation, and the mean value of the tracking error were reduced when using the physical model, as shown in Table 4. In summary, by applying the physical model to the control algorithm, the target value tracking performance was improved.

sec.title: 6 Conclusions
sec.p: This paper presents an EGR control algorithm for a 3.0 l turbocharged diesel engine to enhance the EGR control performance. A mathematical model of the EGR mass flowrate was derived and was used to calculate the feedforward EGR valve position corresponding to the engine operating conditions and the target MAF. A new variable, namely the input–output sensitivity, was proposed to schedule the controller gain more effectively.

Through closed-loop frequency response simulations, the effects of the feedforward control and gain scheduling were examined. Simulation results demonstrated that the proposed feedforward control and gain-scheduling approach improved the target value tracking performance.

To validate the proposed control algorithm, engine experiments using the NEDC were performed. The experimental results showed that the proposed control algorithm allowed more precise control than the conventional controller. In comparison with the conventional control algorithm and the proposed algorithm, the r.m.s. and maximum values of the target tracking error were reduced by 2.5 per cent and 8.0 per cent respectively. By using the proposed EGR control algorithm, time-consuming experiments for controller calibration can be reduced as the lookup tables are substituted by a mathematical model of the EGR valve.
